definition: creating a sequence of instructions to enable the computer to do something
opposite_reasoning: PhysicalConstruction provides the strongest semantic opposition to ComputerProgramming along meaningful dimensions: (1) abstract/digital vs. concrete/physical domain, (2) symbolic manipulation vs. material assembly, (3) intangible vs. tangible outputs. Both are creative, skilled processes that produce functional artifacts, making them parallel but opposite. This opposition is more coherent than generic 'physical labor' because it maintains the 'construction/creation' semantic while flipping the domain. For Fisher-LDA, this provides a clean axis separating digital/symbolic processes from physical/material processes. While not directly relevant to deception detection, it establishes a fundamental process-type distinction useful for concept space organization.
